awd_titl_txt: Developing A Discourse Observation Tool and Online Professional Development to Promote Science, Oral Language and Literacy Development from the Start of School
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. The goal of this project is to develop resources and a professional development model to help early-elementary teachers improve science instruction among young learners by cultivating scientific discourse.  A central component of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) is engaging students in discourse with a focus on formulating and communicating scientific explanations.  This project will develop a classroom observation tool that will help teachers examine changes in the quantity and quality of science discourse in K-2 classrooms over time.  The project will also develop an online professional development (PD) model that uses the new observation tool to help teachers analyze their own classroom practices and the practice of others to improve classroom efforts to foster improved scientific discourse. 

 This early stage design and development study will employ a Design-Based Implementation Research (DBIR) approach to develop the new classroom observation tool and online professional development model, and then seek answers to the following research questions: 1) How can a classroom observation measure be developed to effectively capture the range in quality of science discourse in early elementary classrooms?;  2) How can an online PD model be developed based on the new observation tool?; 3) How do teachers' knowledge and instructional practice change over the course of participation in the yearlong PD?; and 4) How does the quantity and quality of science discourse change in K-2 classrooms over the course of teachers' participation in a yearlong online PD experience that is built around the new observation tool?  The project will engage 36 teachers and their 36 different classrooms in Michigan and use multiple data sources to understand whether and how teacher knowledge and instructional practices change during participation in the new PD model.  Multiple iterations of design, data collection, and refinement will be used to understand how, when, and why features of the PD and observation tool might combine to transform science discourse in early elementary classrooms.  In years 3 and 4, the project team will conduct two year-long implementation trials with cohorts of 15 teachers and 5 instructional coaches (experienced science teachers) who will use the PD and tool in order study their implementation and make iterative improvements. The project will also gather data to understand changes in teacher knowledge and practice as well as video data to document changes in classroom discourse.

por.por_cntn:
The Next Generation Science Standards set ambitious goals for children’s learning that integrate science practices, crosscutting concepts, and disciplinary core ideas beginning in kindergarten. Likewise, English Language Arts standards set high expectations for disciplinary literacy at the start of elementary school. To support our youngest children in learning aligned with these standards, teachers must provide scaffolded and developmentally appropriate opportunities to begin participating in science and disciplinary literacy practices from the start of school. Teaching that supports children in engaging in these practices emphasizes talk that focuses on making children’s ideas the center of instruction and supporting children in engaging in productive sensemaking. However, without support, teachers may find it challenging to engage children in these types of rich discussions. Therefore, the goal of this DRK-12 project, Developing A Discourse Observation Tool and Online Professional Development to Promote Science, Oral Language and Literacy Development from the Start of School (SOLID Start), was to develop a formative observation tool and aligned online professional learning (PL) to support kindergarten-2nd grade (K-2) teachers in engaging children in sensemaking science talk.

We designed and iteratively tested a formative discourse observation tool (the SOLID Start Tool) that was used as part of online PL with instructional coaching. In order to design this tool we engaged in a systematic literature review that we used to create a framework that described high-quality science talk in three domains: (1) talk that supports equitable science participation and engagement in science; (2) talk that supports deepening science understanding within and across activities; and (3) talk that supports disciplinary literacy for science. Each of these domains included three research-based instructional strategies that coaches and teachers score on a scale of 5 (High) to 1 (Low). Videos of science instruction are segmented into activities (e.g., lesson introduction, exploration, text-based discussion, writing, summary discussion) so that coaches and teachers can use the SOLID Start Tool to consider science talk within different parts of the science lesson. The online PL included: (1) online readings and video resources about science talk; (2) virtual coach-led professional learning communities using the SOLID Start Tool to plan talk in upcoming lessons, and (3) one-on-one meetings with the coach using the SOLID Start Tool to reflect on talk in videos of teachers’ instruction.

To understand which factors may enhance or inhibit the PL and how the PL could be modified to better support teachers, we analyzed interviews, surveys, and videos of PL and classroom instruction from 19 K-2 teachers in Cohort 1. We found that teachers and coaches successfully used the SOLID Start Tool in PL to (1) provide a vision of high-quality science talk; (2) guide reflection on current levels of practice; and (3) guide planning for next steps in instruction. However, both coaches and teachers noted that business-as-usual science curricula (BAU) that teachers used focused on providing information rather than on children’s sensemaking. This made it difficult for teachers to engage children in high-quality science talk because there was little for children to figure out or discuss in these curricula.

Therefore, we modified the PL based on feedback from teachers and coaches so that teachers in Cohort 2 (n=21 K-2 teachers) used the SOLID Start integrated science and literacy curriculum (available for free at solidstart.msu.edu) as they engaged in the PL. The cohort design allowed for a quasi-experimental comparison to see whether changes made between iterations enabled teachers to enact higher quality science talk. We asked whether there were differences in science talk enacted by Cohort 1 (PL with BAU curriculum) and Cohort 2 (PL with SOLID Start Curriculum). 

After coding videos using a coding scheme based on the SOLID Start Tool, our findings show that lessons from Cohort 2 teachers were significantly longer, suggesting that the addition of the curriculum supported teachers in engaging in more science instruction. We also found that, after controlling for time, Cohort 2 teachers engaged in higher quality science talk overall than Cohort 1. Although teachers in Cohort 1 found the PL designed around the SOLID Start Tool to be helpful for their learning about high-quality science talk, BAU curricula limited their implementation of what they learned in the PL. The inclusion of a high-quality K-2 curriculum focused on children’s sensemaking created a more facilitative context for enacting the vision of science talk that the PL supported. 

These findings suggest that to change practices that are challenging for teachers to enact, it is critical to have a coherent system of pedagogical supports that include high-quality curriculum materials as well as aligned PL. This model of free, high-quality curriculum materials with aligned virtual PL may be a scalable way to support teachers in increasing the quantity and quality of science instruction.
